body:
Here is the API method: https://docs.pcloud.com/methods/trash/trash_clear.html

And here is how rclone is calling it

```
2020/01/04 13:30:43 DEBUG : HTTP REQUEST (req 0xc000551800)
2020/01/04 13:30:43 DEBUG : POST /trash_clear?folderid=0 HTTP/1.1
Host: api.pcloud.com
User-Agent: rclone/v1.50.2-104-gc018ebeb-fix-3851-appdata-listr-beta
Content-Length: 0
Authorization: XXXX
Accept-Encoding: gzip
```

```
2020/01/04 13:30:44 DEBUG : HTTP RESPONSE (req 0xc000551800)
2020/01/04 13:30:44 DEBUG : HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Connection: close
Content-Length: 49
Cache-Control: private, max-age=0
Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8
Date: Sat, 04 Jan 2020 13:30:43 GMT
Etag: "cp9FcrQXC7LHQdeUPdbwDByU9hf7"
Server: CloudHTTPd-API v1.1
Vary: Accept-Encoding
X-Error: 1000

{
	"result": 1000,
	"error": "Log in required."
}
```

I don't really understand why that doesn't work - rclone is providing the `Authorization` header...

Do you have support with pcloud?  Maybe you could ask them?
Where do you get the POST url path "/trash_clear" from? According to the API docs it should be "/getfilepublink"?

I also send this support request to pcloud: 

> I am using a third party application (rclone) to communicate with pcloud, using the REST API. There is a problem using the API's "trash_clear" (https://docs.pcloud.com/methods/trash/trash_clear.html) command. When rclone does a POST request to /trash_clear, the error response is 1000 (Log in required.). I noticed the URL on the API page is /getfilepublink, but rclone uses /trash_clear. Is this a problem in your documentation or a problem by clone?

Hello,
Thank you for the e-mail!

Unfortunately, pCloud does not support rclone. The problem might occur because of it.

Kind regards,
Jonathan Teuling,
pCloud Support Team

> Where do you get the POST url path "/trash_clear" from? According to the API docs it should be "/getfilepublink"?

I guess that was in the docs in a previous version...

It looks like a more sensible URL than `getfilepublink` which is described here: https://docs.pcloud.com/methods/public_links/getfilepublink.html

> Unfortunately, pCloud does not support rclone. The problem might occur because of it.

That wasn't very helpful!

Maybe you could emphasize that you are trying to use their public API?

@ncw I did some tests (using curl and python requests) and it looks like the `Bearer` token provided by the OAuth process (which rclone uses) is not accepted by certain methods (all the trash ones, some auth ones, etc.).

I couldn't find any mention of this in their documentation so I assume either it's a bug that likely was introduced when they updated their api.

If, however, we use the `getauth` method with 'username/password' combo, this token is accepted and `trash_list`, `trash_clear`, etc. complete successfully.

I have sent them a mail (without mentioning rclone) so let's see what they say.

Update: I received a reply from pCloud.

> Hello,
> 
> Thank you for taking the time to contact pCloud's Technical Support. My name is Stefan and I will be happy to assist you.
> 
> Please excuse us for the inconvenience but note that we do not provide dedicated API support so I'm unable to advise you on how to use the code.
> The information we can provide is only at the link below as you have already found out yourself.
> https://docs.pcloud.com/

That sucks and brings down my opinion of pCloud.

So, the option is for rclone to switch to `getauth` instead of using `OAuth` for all the methods to work.

> I did some tests (using curl and python requests) and it looks like the `Bearer` token provided by the OAuth process (which rclone uses) is not accepted by certain methods (all the trash ones, some auth ones, etc.).
> 
> I couldn't find any mention of this in their documentation so I assume either it's a bug that likely was introduced when they updated their api.

Sounds likely

> If, however, we use the `getauth` method with 'username/password' combo, this token is accepted and `trash_list`, `trash_clear`, etc. complete successfully.

Interesting.

`getauth` has the disadvantage that rclone needs to store the password in the config file. It would hardly be the first backend to do that, but it is annoying since oauth already works nearly!

What did you say in your email? Maybe you should rephrase it as a bug report that the clear trash API works with a token from `getauth` but not from OAuth - that might get some traction? Or maybe you did this already!

> `getauth` has the disadvantage that rclone needs to store the password in the config file. It would hardly be the first backend to do that, but it is annoying since oauth already works nearly!

I forget what the expiry was for the `getauth` token but storing the password could be optional. Let the user know that storing the password would auto refresh the token when needed failing which the user needs to keep an eye in the logs.

But, yeah, I wouldn't mind storing the user/pass if required. As you said, not the only remote that does this.

> What did you say in your email? Maybe you should rephrase it as a bug report that the clear trash API works with a token from `getauth` but not from OAuth - that might get some traction? Or maybe you did this already!

Yeah, I said exactly that. I explained the bug and even the errors in the documentation. Maybe they use another API or the `getauth` method for their in-house clients hence they haven't faced issues themselves, I dunno.

I'm surprised they didn't even acknowledge the clear mistake about `trash_clear` method where it says `getfilepublink` in the documentation.

@accountForIssues do you want to have a go at adding the password into the config and using it for those methods?

Remember the code will need to be backwards compatible with no password set.
@ncw I have never programmed using Go but I'm definitely interested in learning it. This could be a good way to learn by example. I would like to take a stab at it but cannot promise anything.
